headline.main: U.S. SOCIAL TOLERANCE OF DRUGS FOUND ON RISE

docs.lead_paragraph: Social scientists believe that the level of public tolerance of the use of illegal drugs is continuing to rise in all levels of American society. They say, further, that the growing availability and acceptability of these drugs is effecting profound social changes that have neither been fully acknowledged nor fully understood. The signs of the raised level of acceptance are widespread. At a rehearsal break in a recent Manhattan practice session of an Ivy League alumni choral group that counts stockbrokers, lawyers and corporate executives among its membership, one successful businessman held out a bit of hashish to a fellow singer, aged 49. ''Have some?'' he asked.

docs.lead_paragraph: A number of readers have expressed concern or confusion about the following health-related topics that have been in the news recently or have been discussed in this column. 'Desirable' Weights Several months ago word reached an inordinately weight-conscious American public that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company was going to increase the allowable poundage on its ideal-weight-forheight charts. For a few perpetual dieters who never quite got down to the numbers posted next to the doctor's scale, the news was cause for celebration - a piece of cheesecake or a hot fudge sundae, if not a dinner out. This month the insurance company finally released its new tables, updating the original ones published in 1959. For some people, especially relatively short men and women, the new numbers represent a significant gain - a 15-pound increase for short men with small frames, 11 pounds for short women with medium frames, tapering down to just a 2-pound increment for tall men with small or medium frames and a 1-pound gain for tall women with small frames.
